She was big, yes, incredibly big, but she
was strong and active and stood upright to
threaten his two operatives at Brooks two days
ago when Turner tried to use their presence to
coerce her.


No, she was still around, still a threat,
still growing and growing.
His phony citizen's militia alert had started
a world-class brouhaha inside the halls of the
Department of Justice and just about every major metropolitan police department in the country,
with dismally unproductive results.
Perhaps a judicious leak or two to the national
mass media would shake the tree,
but Lang was leery of using the press.



They were controllable, but only
to a degree--public opinion could sway them
against the government agencies they
depended on for quotes and information.
No, no; the press must stay out of it, for now.


Lang stopped pacing momentarily and
looked around the DART headquarters.
He had called in the entire team for this operation
twenty five of the best trained, most loyal
soldiers in the country.
Half were asleep in their quarters in another
building next door, recovering from a full day
of effort and a half-day's flight from
New York to Johnston.


They had stuffed the massive glove
box with a variety of items, all taken from
the Porter girl's home and the office of her
family doctor. Lang altered his path and
strode to the glove box, looking through the
glass at its contents.
Clothing, makeup case, bric-a-brac,
bedsheets, books, other possessions:
all of this woman's life laying inside a
heavy glass-and-metal case.


Lang permitted himself to speculate on why
this young annoying girl was steadily growing
into a massive giantess.
The mass of personal effects she possessed
seemed to diminish the theory of her
being a recent extraterrestrial immigrant
but that could be an elaborate ploy to fool
an investigator like himself.


He continued to seeth and theorize and inspecting
the Porter girl’s belongings until boom pay-dirt.
He found a family bible.
In it Lisa parents names.


Lang grinned and sent 3 DART Members
to Sacred Hearts Church to learn more.
1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Lisa’s New Life ch 60 -reserved-

1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chapter 66: Dark Discoveries

The Carter Property
Polk County, North Carolina
Friday June 11 2010


“Michael I really appreciate your company,"
Lisa said,
“but you don’t have to stay beside me all day long."


Lisa was on her elbows and knees in her
tent-bedroom. Despite his obvious
connections to several companies
Michael had made no move in the last two days
to leave her side except for short periods
of time to meet with other co-workers.


Even Brian had remarked on his absence from
his work. Lisa leaned forward on her elbows to
bring herself closer to Michael and she realized
he had to crane his neck to look at her.


God, I'm getting so big, she thought.
In a few more days he'll be the size of the
Ken doll I had when I was a little girl.
No, that's wrong--he's not getting smaller,
I'm growing bigger. In a few more days I'll be as
tall as this tent.



Lisa rubbed her chest to ease the fluttering
inside herself. I don't want him to see how
afraid I am of what's happening to me,
how alien I feel.


“But I want to stay beside you, beautiful,"
Michael replied. He reached out and idly
tugged at her braid, his eyes smoldering
as he looked up at her.


Lisa felt her affection for Michael grow even stronger.


"You are so beautiful, Lisa," he said suddenly,
his tone softened.
"I just want to stand here and look
at you all the time. Besides, I'm now officially on
sabbatical from most of my pressing work”


“Really? You did that for me?”


“For you Lisa I’d do anything.
You are first and foremost in my mind”


Lisa blushed and her heart fluttered.

Michael changed the topic suggesting that
they get some exercise.


The weather outside had changed again.
The weather lately had been becoming as strange
and unpredictable as Pittsburgh or the lottery ever
since Lisa had arrived at the estate.


Currently it had become winter like in only a couple
of days despite being June.


As Lisa lifted the flap for Michael
a cold gust of wind almost pulled the cloth
from her hands.
The sky was dappled by tall cumulus clouds,
white above and dark gray below,
scudding before the wind.
The snow of the previous night had melted
in the morning sunshine,
leaving a raw dampness in the air.


Michael wrapped a nylon web belt around
his middle and attached a canteen and
a cellular phone.



"What all the well-dressed joggers are wearing,
nowadays," he said.
He rubbed his arms, looked up at the
sky in a considering way, then grinned.



"A soft day," he said. "Come on."


They walked, jogged and joked for awhile
then they heard a sound near the lake.
Carefully they went to investigate.


Can you see anything?" Michael asked.
Lisa leaned to one side, then to the other.


"Yes," she replied.
"There's this big boat with a striped awning
heading this way. It looks like it's full of kids."

"Kids? Oh, it must be another enviro-cruise,"
Michael said.


"A what?"


"A guy named Joe Farnsworth runs a
bait-and-tackle shop on the other
end of the lake," Michael explained.


"He's been offering his party boat for tours
by the local schools to show the kids the
lake environment. To boost his income
during the slow season or slow periods."


"Oh, yes, I see now," Lisa said.
She had focused on the boat a hundred
yards away and saw
FARNSWORTH BAIT & TACKLE stenciled
in yellow near its prow.


"Michael , I don't think those kids are
more than eight years old. They sure look cold."


The guttural sound of the boat's engine rose
and fell, sputtering occasionally.
Michael cocked his ear towards the noise.


"Hope whoever's running that thing doesn't break
down out there. I doubt there'll be anybody
available to give him a tow."


Lisa smiled and watched the gaggle of
well-wrapped children standing in the craft,
all wearing bright orange life preservers,
holding tightly to its metal handrails.



The boat was obviously old, its wooden hull gray.
The engine sputtered and a backfired with a
resounding echo, then its noise stopped.



The boat, now perhaps fifty yards from the shore,
began drifting in their direction.


"That figures." Michael snorted again.
"Well, if they can't get it started I'll call Farnsworth
and tell him he needs to retrieve his boat."


Lisa focused her full attention on the boat.
She could hear high-pitched voices
chattering animatedly as a
counterpoint to a low conversation from
the three older people in the boat.



One adult figure walked to the rear of the boat
and yanked at something below
the gunwale. As a hatch cover came up
she saw a tendril of smoke rise from the
rear of the boat.
In a few seconds the tendril became a
churning mass fanned across the boat
by the breeze.


“Michael, that boat's on fire,"
Lisa said.


Michael thrust himself into the brush to
get a clear view.


"Oh, shit!" He yanked his phone from his belt.
Lisa stood fully erect, bringing her head
above the brush for a clearer view.
She saw gusts of white against the black
smoke as another adult applied an extinguisher
to the fire.



A distinct whoosh saw visible flames
flash into the face of the boat's pilot,
who fell out of sight.
The chattering was quickly replaced by
screams and cries as smoke and
fire began to reach out towards
the boat's passengers.


Lisa gulped, breathing heavily as she
saw the kids all rush to the bow of the
boat, pressing closely together.
The children began to abandon the
boat in the face of the smoke and fire,
some jumping overboard, some being pushed,
struggling as their clothes became waterlogged.



The chorus of tiny voices screaming in fear and
panic was nerve-shattering.


“Michael—-“ Lisa began.

Michael had the phone to his ear,
talking quickly and urgently.
She clenched her hands into fists and
jumped through the brush,
running to the small beach beyond the path,
splashing into the water.


Her feet slipped on sand and mud as
she made her way out to the boat,
which was now fully afire.
The water came up to her knees,
her thighs, her waist.
She kept moving, wading out until she was
up to her chest in the cold
water--and within arm's reach of the kids
floating around the boat.


“Swim to me, swim to me,"
Lisa called out.
She cupped one child--a pretty blond-haired girl--
in her hand and swept her up to her shoulder.
The little girl, choking and spitting,
lay face down on the warm, dry surface.


Lisa reached out for more, wading around
the boat, moving quickly but gently.
One pitch-headed boy looked at her and
realized how big his rescuer was.


"PISSFUCKBULLSHIT!" he yelled,
his dark eyes round.


“It's all right, don't be afraid, swim to me,"
Lisa said softly.
He slowly began to dog-paddle towards her.
She raised her hand beneath him,
lifting him clear and prompting another
round of obscenities. Other kids, hearing
Lisa calling and seeing their compatriots l
out of the water on her shoulders,
swam clumsily towards her.



In a moment she had eight of the children
clinging to her. She turned carefully to
head towards the shore.
The other children, seeing her leave,
began screaming and crying, paddling
frantically in an effort to get closer to her.
1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Lisa’s New Life ch 61 -reserved-

1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chapter 67: Dark Discoveries Part I

"I'll be back, I'll be back for you,"
she called over her shoulder at the others.
She saw Michael , waist deep in the water,
waving to her urgently.


"I called Brian," he shouted.
"He's got the rescue squad on the way."


"Can you help the people in the boat?
I'll get the rest of the kids," she called back.


Michael had already dived into the water and
stroked past her. Lisa continued to the shore,
her passengers squeaking as she moved.


“It's all right, it's okay, I won't let you fall,"
she said softly, placing hands and forearms
over her squirming charges.
She stepped ashore and knelt,
then dropped to her elbows and tilted l
herself forward.



The eight children came free against
her arms, slipping unharmed to the pebbly
beach. Lisa stood quickly.


"I'll be right back. You stay put,"
she said, then turned and ran back
into the water. Two of the children,
more energetic than the others, had
managed to swim almost to the shallows
and she lifted them up, depositing them on shore.


The others tried to follow but fell behind.
Lisa waded out knee-deep to capture each
one and place them where the water came
only to their ankles. She had eighteen children
sitting or lying on the beach when she turned
back to the boat.


Michael had swum to the boat, which now
burned like a smoky torch.
One of the adult passengers--a teenager, really--had
leaped from the boat and was now treading
water, a look of sheer terror on his face as
Lisa charged towards him.
She slowed and reached out to him.


"Here," she said. "Take my hand."


The teenager blinked, his teeth chattering.
Lisa slipped her hand through the water
underneath him and lifted him up, gripping
him around his hips. He grabbed Lisa's fingers spasmodically as she lifted him clear of the water.


"Shit, shit, shit SHITSHIT!" he yelled,
looking around wildly.


"Stop that," Lisa said in a soft but firm voice.
"You need to help the kids."



She returned to the shore and released
the teenager, then dashed back.
Michael was treading water near the boat,
partially obscured by the smoke pouring
from its hull, trying unsuccessfully
to get another of the older passengers
off the prow of the boat.



“I-I can't swim," this teenager--a girl--cried.


"You like it regular or extra crispy?"
Michael yelled back as best he could,
his exertions to stay afloat robbing him of air.


“Grab one of the cushions and jump!"


The girl looked up and saw
Lisa approaching through the smoke.
She pointed, gave a strange, strangled squeak,
then fell in a heap inside the boat.


"Michael, don't--"
Lisa called out, but it was too late.
Michael had already grabbed the
gunwale of the boat and levered
himself on board.


Lisa waded out further, the water suddenly
rising past her shoulders to her neck and chin.
She hooked a finger on the gunwale
of the boat and pulled.
Even though it was as big as she was tall
the boat surged easily towards her and
she started wading backwards,
coughing from the choking black smoke
of the fire.



Michael abruptly appeared through
the deadly fog, the teenager hung over
his shoulder.


“Lisa Take her, I'm going for the pilot," he called.


"Michael, be--" Lisa called back,
her stomach in knots with worry for
his safety. Michael dropped the girl into
Lisa’s hands and thrust himself
back into the smoke.


Lisa continued to tow the boat to
shore with one hand and held the girl
halfway out of the water with the other.


"Michael! Michael!"



Lisa released the boat and supported him as
Michael jumped overboard and began to swim slowly beside her.

Loud coughing erupted from the smoke.
Michael reappeared, dragging the
boat's pilot under his arms.
Lisa could see the third teenager was
burned on his arms and face, his hair charred.


"Fuck a dog!" Michael yelled.


"Michael, you're hurt," Lisa cried.
His hands were bright red and she
could see tiny droplets of blood appearing
on his skin. She tugged at the boat with
all her strength and felt the wood give
under her fingers.


“Gotta abandon the ship,"
Michael said, hacking.
He slung the pilot over the railing and
lowered him into the water.
Lisa released the boat and supported
him as Michael jumped overboard and
began to swim slowly beside her.



The breeze shifted sufficiently to keep
the smoke from the group of survivors
as they lay on the small beach.
Lisa walked slowly from the water,
a teenager dangling from either hand.


Michael followed, shaking his scorched fingers.
The children were sitting in a gaggle,
crying and shivering.
As Lisa rose up from the water high over
him the unharmed teenage boy fell flat l
and covered his head with his arms.
The pitiful sounds the children were making
struck Lisa's heart.


"Oh, here, don't cry, you're going to be okay,"
she said softly. Several of the children
had recovered their wits sufficiently to
realize a twenty-foot tall giant was stepping
towards them and they tried backing away
from her on hands and feet, one whimpering
in fear.


Lisa put her two charges down on the beach.
She sat on her heels and reached
out to each child in turn, gathering
them closely together.


“Michael these kids need to get warm," she said.
“How long do you think the rescue people will be?"



"A while," he panted.
“I'm the nearest fire-paramedic, I'm afraid."


Lisa turned to look down at Michael, who was
still waving his hands in the cold air.


“Michael, are you badly hurt?"

"No, no, I'm fine. I'll attend to the three
big kids if you'll take care of the little ones.
They need to get out of those coats before
they catch their death from exposure."



Lisa nodded and returned to the children.
Murmuring reassurances she leaned
carefully over the children.
She noticed the little blond girl she
had first rescued was sitting nearest to her,
her mouth open, shivering visibly.



“What's your name?"
Lisa asked. The little girl looked up.


"Kathy," she gasped.


"Kathy, my name's Lisa.
Let's see about getting you out of those
wet things so you can warm up."
Lisa smiled and slowly reached out with
both hands, grasping the life preserver
the girl wore. She tried to unsnap the
bulky vest but her fingers were too big to
work its clasp. She gripped the vest front
and yanked, neatly snapping the webbing,
then carefully drew it from around the girl.



Lisa turned to the next child,
who squeaked as her giant hands came near.


“It's all right. I won't hurt you. What's your name?"


"B-B-Billy."


"I won't hurt you, Billy, but you need to
get out of that life jacket so we can
get you warm, okay?"


Lisa patiently worked her way through
the crowd of children, smiling and
speaking softly. Some of the children
were so cold they couldn't speak
through their shivering.


"Michael, these kids need something to
warm them," Lisa said.
Michael looked up from the three
teenagers whom he had laid out on the
beach and nodded.


“These three are non-smokers--no
way to make a fire except the
boy-scout way, and I was never a boy scout."
"Next time I go jogging I'm bringing matches," he replied.
1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Lisa’s New Life ch  62 -reserved-

1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chapter 68: Dark Discoveries Part I|

Lisa looked around.
The boat had finally drifted on shore some
distance away, pushed by the breeze,
smoldering and half-sunk.
Her sweatsuit was sopping, as was Michael's.


Eighteen kids needed a source of warmth
but there was none to be had--


"I know," she said suddenly.
Lisa stood and rolled her sweatshirt up
over her breasts.



“Michael, I'm going to lie on my side.
Put the kids next to me," she called.
Michael had stopped attending the burned
teen as he watched Lisa start to pull her shirt up,
a puzzled look on his face, then he smiled.


Lisa stretched out on the beach.
Michael grabbed up each child,
stripped off their outer garments,
and braced them up against Lisa.


"Michael they're like ice," she said.


"I know. Can you drape your arm across them?
That way they'll be warm front and back,"
he said, gasping for air as he hefted the
last little boy and nested him next to his.



Lisa complied, angling her shoulders and
pressing her forearms and hands gently
against the children. She could feel them
shaking.
Michael stopped on his way back to the three
older kids to give Lisa a quick peck on the lips.
Lisa saw he was pale and his lips were turning white.



"Beautiful and smart, too," he said.


"Michael , you're freezing!"


"Yeah, a little. Nothing a nice hot toddy wouldn't fix."


Lisa kept watch over her charges,
whispering softly to them.
She could feel some of them stop shaking
but others still shivered, shocked by
their experience.
One boy, the smallest of the group,
had curled up under her hand, shuddering
violently, and she clasped him to her
palm to give him the most warmth she could.



She continued to speak softly and
reassuringly as they warmed against
her belly and ribs, shifting against her
as she breathed.



"Wow, you're big, lady," one boy opined.
"Bigger than my big brother or my Mommy,
or even my Dad."


Lisa stifled a giggle at the little boy’s
portentous tone--she would bounce the
children against her belly if she did--and
craned her head as far as possible to view
all the children she held.

"Is everybody okay?" she said.


"Uh-huh." "Yeah." "I think so." "No!"

A loud roar heralded the arrival of a vehicle.
Lisa started and turned her head, looking up the
path they had used to reach the lake.


Michael also noted the noise and looked up,
then relaxed as a four-wheel drive truck thumped
around the brush into view,
Brian at the wheel.
The truck slid to a stop and Brian leaped out.



“Brian! Good, I'm afraid my phone is drowned,"
he called.



Brian opened the hatchback of the truck
and a mass of blankets spilled out.
Michael jumped up to help.
Brian paused in approaching Lisa,
looking at the children ranged along her belly.
He smiled and nodded, then began to
draw the children from under her arms
and wrap each one of them in a blanket.



"Brian, Michael's hurt," Lisa said. Brian nodded.


"Yes, I saw. I'll attend to him in a moment," he replied.
1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Lisa’s New Life ch  63 -reserved-

1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chapter 69: Dark Discoveries Part II



Lisa rose and pulled down her top after
the last child was wrapped in a blanket.
She stepped over to where Michael had been
attending the three teen supervisors of the children.
The burned one was in a bad way, his face and arms blistered.



The girl looked up at the approaching
giantess and collapsed again into a faint.
The other unharmed boy averted his eyes
and stared at the ground, shaking.
Michael's amused, sardonic expression could
not entirely hide his own distress and shock
from the injury to his hands.



“Michael , you need help," Lisa said.
Michael looked up at her.


"I'll be okay, sweetheart.
This guy needs the real attention."


"Allow me to care for them, Mr. Gail,"
Brian said, stepping up to them.
He waved one hand at the children, now all
huddled together under the blankets.


"The rescue people will be here momentarily.
It would prevent a great many silly questions if
neither of you were present when they arrive."
He paused to look up at Lisa and beamed.



"I will watch the children until they can be
transported to hospital. Here, Miss Porter,"
he said, offering her a covered roll of
gauze and a small tube.



"Take Mr. Gail home and clean his hands
carefully with cold water, then spread this
cream on the affected areas and wrap them
well with the gauze.
I should be able to return within the hour
and look at Mr. Gail's injuries more closely."



“Michael, he's right,"
Lisa said, suddenly shy of meeting other people.
Michael gathered himself to argue, then nodded.
He tried rubbing his arms with his hands and
grimaced in pain.


"Come on," Lisa said, slipping the first aid
supplies into a growth-fold of her shirt and
lifting him up.


"Brian, we'll see you back at the house."


“"Very well, Miss Porter," he replied.
Lisa cradled Michael to her and started
to turn for the path when she felt something
grab her ankle.
She looked down and saw the little
blond-haired girl hugging her leg.
Lisa bent down to gently caress the girl with
her free hand.



"See, you're okay, now." She murmured.
The girl said nothing but looked up and
grabbed at Lisa's fingers, trying to hold her back.


"I'm sorry, but I have to go now--Kathy, isn't it?
This man needs help, too,"
Lisa said in apology, smiling down on the girl.



Kathy reluctantly released her hold on
Lisa’s fingers and waved as Lisa began to
walk quickly, back down the path they had come.


"Not that way. The volunteers'll be using the path,"
Michael said.
He pointed out a continuation of the path
leading off to her right.


"Go that way. It leads right back to the house."


Lisa lengthened her stride and walked as
quickly as she could.
Although she did not feel cold at all after her
ducking she could tell that Michael was
not doing as well--he was beginning to shiver
in the breeze of her passage.
When Michael suddenly sneezed
Lisa stopped momentarily.


“"Don't you dare catch cold,on me Michael Porter,"
she said with mock seriousness.
Michael rubbed his nose with his sleeve.



"Me? I don't catch colds,
we just make friends for a bit," he replied.
He started coughing violently, doubling over
from the paroxysms. Lisa frowned with concern.


"What was good for those kids is good for you, too,"
she said, pulling open the neck hole of her shirt and
slipping Michael down her front.
She cradled him through her shirt with one hand.


"Comfy?"


Michael wriggled.
"Your bra's giving me a wedgie," he complained.


“Oh? Okay," Lisa grinned.
She reached under her shirt and slipped
her budding breasts out of their cups.


"Better?"
She felt Michael settle against her cleavage
as her bra rode up her chest and back,
his head and shoulders sticking up out of the
neck hole of her shirt.


"Whoo, you're cold."
She began striding quickly down the path again.



"Thank you," he replied, and sneezed again.
“That does feel better, out of the wind."


Michael was quiet on the journey back.
He had stopped shivering but still sneezed
occasionally and his coughs were wracking him.


Lisa thought about jogging but decided
against the increased speed--
Michael would rattle around inside her
shirt too much. Now that her sudden, unexpected
adventure was over Lisa felt a jumble of emotions.



She realized that all the efforts
Michael had made to protect her from
detection had just gone by the wayside.
She was torn between a sense of reward for
having rescued the children from the burning
boat and shame at having undone 2 weeks of elaborate
effort to keep her unknown to the local populace.


While the children's stories about
her could be discounted as imaginary by
their parents, the three teen monitors would
not be so easily dismissed.


What would they say to the authorities
when they were asked what happened?
Lisa wondered just how long it would
take for the news of the incident to reach
first the state and then federal authorities.


Michael had said that it would take another
several days or so for the airplanes to be
ready for their escape from the reach of the
people who had taken her before.


Lisa tried to focus on the positive thing
she had done--rescuing those kids--but the
problem she had just caused Michael and
herself worked around like grit inside her mind.
Eventually, she voiced her thought.


"Well blew it, didn't I?" she asked.
She slowed her pace and bent her head,
blinking. Then she felt Michael’s arms
encircle her neck firmly, throttling her.


"What?" she asked, stopping and gently pulling
on his arm to ease the sense of choking.
Michael lifted his head from the hollow of
her throat and gave her the brightest smile
she had seen yet.



"I am proud of you," he said.
"I am so proud I could bust.
You are a wonderful person, Lisa Porter.
You saved those children from real harm.
You did so even at your own risks!
I must be the luckiest man in the
world to have you."


Lisa opened her mouth in surprise.
Michael laughed and hugged her neck again.


"You don't believe it's true," he said.
"Believe me, it is. Every word of it.
If you hadn't been there they would've been
burned in the boat, or gone overboard and
drifted halfway down the lake until they were
half-dead from exposure. You saved them Lisa.."



"It was lucky we were both there,
Michael--" Lisa began, picking up
her pace again.




"Uh-uh. Only you could have gotten
those kids out of the water as promptly as
you did. If I'd been there alone I would
have had to swim from boat to shore over
and over again for each kid.


Half of them would've floated away out of my
reach before I could rescue them.
No, you are the reason they're all okay.
You, the twenty-foot woman with the
twelve-foot reach and hands big enough
to cup an eight-year old--only you,
as you are now, could have rescued all
of them so quickly.
And that's all that matters right now."


Michael coughed again.
Lisa felt herself warm from Michael's praise.
She rubbed his body through her shirt and
brushed his head with her chin.
A smile of elation crossed her face, and
she pressed Michael against her and
began to run again.
1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Lisa’s New Life ch  63 -reserved-

1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chapter 70: Dark Discoveries Part III

Under Lisa’s instructions
Michael had gone into the kitchen to retrieve
two small plastic bags and a roll of
adhesive tape, then joined Lisa in her shower-tent.



After stripping herself and unbraiding
her hair she helped him out of his damp clothes.
She drew cold water into her smallest washtub
and dipped Michael's hands in, daintily washing
them, then patted them dry and deftly applied the
ointment and gauze.


Michael stood silently, his expression
bemused as she tended him.
Lisa then wrapped the plastic bags over his
bandaged hands and taped them to his
forearms.



"I promise I won't scratch them," he said.


"This is to keep them dry, silly,"
she answered him.
"Now, let's get the rest of you cleaned up,
and me, too."



She drew hotter water and began to wash
Michael , gently lathering him.
She noticed his member becoming erect.


"I thought you weren't feeling well," she said.


"Not when I'm with a beautiful naked
girl who I love very much,"
Michael replied, his eyes dancing.


"We can soak later," she replied.
Michael looked downcast for a moment,
then winked and gave her his lopsided grin,
spoiling the tableau.
Lisa snorted and soaped him thoroughly, then herself.



“Perverted Baka” she said.


In keeping with recent habit she held him
while rotating under the shower to rinse
them both clean, then she kissed him tenderly.


"Ah, that's better than a hot toddy," he said.
Lisa kissed him again and put him down.
She grabbed up one of her towels and
rubbed him down, then used her hairbrush
to comb his thatch.


"Thank you, sweetheart," he said,
wrapping her towel around himself and
pulling the plastic bags from his hands.


"You're welcome."
Lisa dried and ordered herself, leaving
her hair unbraided.
She stepped into her bedroom-tent and
rummaged among the latest shipment of
clean clothes.


Michael followed.
Lisa was in the process of pulling on a
pair of panties when she noticed him staring.
He looked so much like one of the boys she
had rescued earlier she giggled.


"Like what you see?" she said.
Michael gulped.


"Ah, let me catch my breath and I'll tell you.
You're so beautiful I'm getting dizzy watching you,"
he replied, sitting down on the floor.



“You don't mind, do you?" he asked.


"Never,," she replied, casting a sultry look
in his direction. He blew her a kiss back.
Lisa slipped on a bra, hooking its clasp between
her breasts.


"Do you need that?"
Michael asked. Lisa looked down at herself.
"Not really.” She paused!


"Speaking of which, have you heard
from Professor Odegard?"


"No, not yet," Michael replied.


"I imagine he'll not say anything until he
has something good to report, or nothing
to report at all."



"Do you think he will find out anything?"


"Sure--but he may end up creating more
questions than answers, after all you defy all
known laws of pysics and reason beyond
being beautiful beyond compare"
Michael replied.


Lisa looked down at Michael and blushed at
the compliment.
He was looking in her direction but his eyes
had a faraway look.
He suddenly noticed her staring at him
and he smiled.


"I'm sorry," he said.
"It's just that we both have had quite an
adventure for the last few weeks--you more than me.
I could speculate on the why and wherefore
of what's happening to you but it wouldn't
help matters. I keep thinking about Occam's razor,
though."


"Occam's razor?" she asked.



"William of Occam was an English
scholastic philosopher," Michael said.
"He postulated a view that came to be called
Occam's razor which basically states that the
answer to any problem should never be
made overly complicated.



I keep thinking there is a reason for what's
happened to you, a simple reason. But I can't
come up with one that makes sense, yet.
Augie will help though,
Lisa, and so will I--never worry about that."


Michael coughed.
Lisa finished slipping into the her latest
acquisition, a dress that was half frock,
half kimono delivered the day before, and
hurried across the tent to Michael, bending to rub
his back.



"I think you could use that hot toddy
you've been talking about," She said softly.
“Let's go inside the house. I'd like to see the
inside of it once more while I still can."



"When our new house is built you won't
have that problem,"
Michael protested.
Lisa smiled to dispel his obvious distress
at her concern and swept him off her his feet.

"I know, --and thank you."


“"Okay, pretty lady," he replied.
He looked so relieved at her smile it was
almost comical.



“let's get ourselves some refreshment.
Rescuing a boatload of kids before lunch
is exhausting work."
He held up his watch for Lisa to read.
It was one in the afternoon.
Lisa shook her head.
Not having slept in three days it was
becoming harder and harder for Lisa to reckon
the passage of time accurately without a
timepiece.
She carried him from her tent to the house.
1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Lisa’s New Life ch  64 -reserved-

1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chapter 71: Dark Discoveries Part 4

The Edneyville Medical Center
Gail Memorial Hospital
Edneyville, North Carolina
Friday June 11, 2010
Aprox 330pm


Polk County Sheriff Russell Thompson
pressed his uniform hat firmly on his head
against the afternoon breeze as he strode
towards his patrol car in the hospital's parking lot,
his mind full of questions.


He had raced to the Medical Center in Henderson
county to visit one of the victims of the
morning boating accident,
his eight-year old daughter Kathy.
When he had arrived the emergency
room of the hospital was a scene of chaos.


Half of the twenty-one children and
teens involved in the event were clumped
on hospital gurneys lining the hallway while
the rest lay on beds in the ER.
One of the teens was in the process of
being transferred to the adjacent connected building
to the facility's
burn center with second and third-degree burns
over twenty percent of his body,
but he was the only serious injury.




Thompson was puzzled by the reactions of
the rest of the accident victims.
His little blond-haired girl was more excited
than scared or hurt, an attitude shared
by almost all the other children.
He had swept her into his arms and hugged her,
only to have her giggle in his ear.


"I'm okay, Daddy," she said after he had
assured himself she was all right.


“A big lady saved us from the lake."


"You saw a big lady?" he had asked.
"Big like Mommy?"


"Bigger. Lots bigger! Real big,"
Kathy had said, waving her hand over her
head in emphasis.


One of his female deputies approached him
and told him she had been given the same
story by Billy Archer, a classmate of Kathy's.
Thompson decided that making what
probably was a terrifying experience into an
adventure was a healthy reaction by the kids.
But after his tall, willowy wife Matilda had
come to the hospital and taken charge
of their daughter Thompson began
to orchestrate an investigation into the
accident and the peculiar emphasis
on "the big lady" became distracting.




The two unhurt teens were shaking from
hysteria and
closed-mouthed about the accident--the girl
especially would begin to shake every
time the subject of their rescue came up, and
the boy suddenly admitted how he had
been a regular methamphetamine user
for a year but promised to give it up.



"I was having heavy hallucinations
out on the boat, man," the boy had said.


"I was so stressed I dreamed this woman
who swam out to help us was huge.
I mean, huge! I dreamed she lifted me out of the
water and carried me to the
shore, man. It was weird."


Most of the kids also seemed obsessed
with the idea of a "big lady".
One boy related how she held him in her
hand to warm him when he was shivering
all over from being in the water.
Thompson's wife told him she was beginning
to be worried about Kathy because she wanted
to see "the giant lady" again.



Even more puzzling was the reaction
of the hardworking chief internist
and hospital administrator, Joann Canfield.
After overhearing the children talking Thompson
saw Doctor Canfield's eyes grow wide,
then she suddenly started guffawing
and excused herself from the emergency room.



Thompson had tried to ask about her
unusual reaction but she had just shaken
her head, convulsed with laughter.
It was strange, unusual--hinky.
Save for the burned boy all the kids had
come through remarkably well from the
boating accident, a happy event.
But something was wrong, something
didn't jibe, something didn't make sense.



Then there was the fax his office
received that morning.
Originated by the North Carolina Department of Investigation, it relayed an alert issued by the U.S. Department of Justice about a weapons
theft from a military base in Texas days ago,
which involved "possible biological weapons materials"
and the reported use of airplanes.



Thompson had received complaints
from one resident about low-flying jet
airplanes flying
that night from Michael Gail's private airstrip
and the fax mentioned someone identified
only as "Mike or Michael" as the leader of this new, apparently violent citizen's militia group.



Thompson did not automatically accept the
information as valid; his own experience
with federal authorities had not exactly been
reassuring--a DEA raid on a purported drug
lab in Polk County turned into an embarrassing
experience for a combination
federal-state-local law enforcement task
force and a frightening experience for an
eighty-year old grandmother whose
only drug habit was prescription medications
for arthritis--but an interview with
Gail was certainly in order.



Too many things happened over the
last couple of days or so--too many strange things.
Hinky.
Thompson didn't like hinky things
happening in his jurisdiction.



Twenty five minutes of rapid driving found him
back in Polk County on Reservoir Road.
After passing the deputy stationed at the
junction of the road with the highway he slowed,
following the macadam bordering the
Green river, heading for the reservoir and
the Gail property.



Thompson had only met Gail a couple of times
in Columbus three years ago, when he
had proposed bringing new businesses
to the county.
Those businesses had generated tremendous
returns and the resulting revenue permitted a
ten percent drop in county taxes.


Those businesses also boosted local economic
circumstances so well that they had achieved
the lowest unemployment and poverty in the
country.



Gail was a philanthropist, too, funding
the building of that new hospital in
Edneyville and expansions to the medical campus
and an additional 2 wings onto the college there,
as well as a new school building in Columbus,
the free senior clinic in Tryon--
and the new,
fully-equipped state-of-the-art patrol
cars he and his deputies were using
as well as renovations to 3 police stations
and 4 fire stations in the surrounding counties.


Gail had been pleasant if quiet, Thompson recalled.
1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Lisa’s New Life ch  65 -reserved-

1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chapter 72 : Dark Discoveries Part 5

Near the Gail Estate
Private Road
Friday June 11, 2010
Aprox 545pm




Still, reports from his deputies indicated a
dozen delivery trucks a day rolling up this road
recently, and what about those mystery flights
from his private airstrip three nights ago?
Thompson needed some answers and
this seemed the place to start.


Thompson's hinky meter rose several
notches as Gail's house came into view.
Two huge tents abutted the home and he
could see another tall structure hidden in some
conifers a few hundred feet away.
The tents were a featureless white
in color--nothing like the equipment available
for rental from Asheville.



Crates were stacked neatly outside the
outermost tent.
Thompson drove up the driveway and
parked his car before the front entrance.
It was nearly 6p.m. and the cloud-dappled sky was darkening--another mysterious cold front was
coming down from the north, promising the
possibility of snow flurries tonight.



Thompson shook his head. Distracting
himself by wondering about the weather
was not going to get him any answers.
He thumped his way up the steps to the front door
and rang the bell.


On the third ring the door abruptly opened.
He saw the Indian-looking butler of the house,
who smiled and bowed him in.


"Is Mr. Gail here?"


"Yes, sir," the butler replied.
Thompson couldn't help feeling the man was
concerned about something.
The hinky meter jumped another notch.


"If you will please follow me I will
bring you to him."


Thompson followed the butler through a
hallway to the main floor of the home.
He was impressed by the house, his eyes
professionally noting the furnishings and fittings.
No wonder this Mr Gail had installed
a custom-made security system.



He was led around a corner and found
Gail sitting at his desk. Gail rose immediately,
a smile on his face.


"Hello, Sheriff Thompson,"
he said, smiling broadly.
He held up his two hands, which were
wrapped in gauze.



"Please pardon me for not offering my hand.
I'm afraid I got a little burned this morning.
Do you want to speak to me about the
accident at the lake?"


"Yes," Thompson replied.
His hinky meter just went off
scale--this man was nothing like the quiet,
taciturn speaker at those county board meetings
three years ago.
He was smiling and relaxed if
a little pale in the light.
He waved Thompson into the living area.



"May I get you something? Coffee?
Something with alcohol in it?
Brian, a cup of coffee for our guest, please.
Now, what can I do for you?"


"I'd like to hear what happened this
morning at the reservoir," Thompson replied as
Gail led him to the furniture in front of the
fireplace and waved him into a chair.
The butler appeared at his elbow and he
accepted the proffered cup and saucer.


Gail spoke quickly and easily, relating how
he and a guest had been jogging near the
lake that morning when they observed the
boat on fire and how they had helped the
children ashore.



"That was a very brave thing you did,"
Thompson said.


"I must tell you my little girl was among
the kids in that boat. I'd like to thank
you personally for saving her."


"Oh, no problem," Gail said, flushing and
waving his hand.


"Where is your guest? I'd like to speak to him, too," Thompson said, sipping his coffee.


Michael shook his head.
"I am afraid she had a business appointment
in New York at three," he replied.



"I can try to call her for you or
get her number if you like."


She? Her? A woman?
Thompson sat back in his chair.
How did she leave?
His deputy had been at the crossroads since
just after noon to keep out the overly curious
until the investigation was completed,
who had reported no one leaving the
Gail property; and, he had already been told by
his female deputy that her husband, a mechanic at Beddington Airframes, had called to tell her he
was going to be late getting home because they
were still working on both of the airplanes
Gail had used in the past.


Gail was lying--but why?
The hinky meter was rattling.


"What's her name?"


“Lisa Porter I met her on the way home
from a friend trying to set me up an out
of town blind date.
We, ah, had an understanding,
if you know what I mean.
The kids were okay, then? No serious injuries?"



"They were all right as rain. You flew this
Miss Porter here?”


“Miss Porter yes”


Thompson leaned forward and watched
Gail's face carefully.
He detected just the tiniest flicker of concern in
the younger man's expression as he replied to
his question.


The hinky meter was spinning around its dial now.


"You do understand I am conducting
an investigation into the accident,
Mr. Gail. I really need to speak to this Miss Porter."



"I'm sorry, sheriff. I didn't know she would
be needed for your investigation.
Like I said, I can get her number for you."


“I would appreciate it, Mr. Gail,"
Thompson replied.
He looked around the vast room admiringly.


"You're not doing any remodeling or
building, are you?"

"No. Why?"


"Those two big tents outside, and the
other tent off in the woods there,"
Thompson replied.



"I assumed you were engaged in some
serious building here. Brand new, from the look
of them. Are you working on another project?"


"No, not at all. The tents are for storage."


Storage? And with a dozen trucks
rumbling up the road every day for several days.
The hinky meter exploded.
Thompson made a show of sitting
back in his chair, and sipped noisily
from his coffee.
1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Lisa’s New Life ch 66. -reserved-

1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chapter 73 : Dark Discoveries Part 6

Gail Estate
Friday June 11, 2010
Aprox 610pm



"Boy, that's a lot of storage room
you've got there.
Those two tents together are bigger
than your house.
Can I take a look inside them?"




"Why do you want to look inside my tents?"


"No reason, Mr. Gail.
But, I am responsible for public safety
and I would appreciate it if you could
satisfy my concerns over what you have inside
those tents."


"Sure, I see no reason why not," Gail answered.
He was far too glib, Thompson thought,
too glib by half.
The guy was doing a good job of covering
his real reasons for the tents, but not good enough.



"Also, I've been told that there's been a
lot of traffic rolling through Columbus
headed this way.
Are you sure you're not working on some
special project?
I can assure you I won't tell anyone."



"No, no special project."
Gail was now frowning, his eyes mirrored
with concern.


"Oh, and by the way, while I'm here,
I guess I should tell you that my office
received a complaint from old Mack
Hostetler just on the other side of the
hill here," Thompson continued.



"Seems that you had two flights the other
night and he was unhappy with
the noise--flying in from the west takes you
right over his property.
Funny how he didn’t complain about the
flight this afternoon, though.
Since his son's a member of the
Polk County Legislature he figures he
has a direct line to my office. Funny old coot."



Thompson watched Gail's face fall. He smiled.


"Mr. Gail, what's really going on here?
What's with those big tents out there?
Who is this Miss Porter of yours, really?
What really happened at the reservoir today?"
he asked, leaning back in his chair.



He watched Michael hesitate and
nervously lick his lips.


“Michael” a female voice suddenly
called into the room.
Thompson was seated facing the fire so
the voice came from behind him.
He twisted his barrel chest in his chair
to get a look at the owner of the voice.


“Michael, I think the sheriff wants the truth
and we should give it to him," the voice said.
Thompson saw
Michael look down the anteroom behind his chair.


Thompson watched
Michael point his chin up towards
the ceiling--and up.
His face was filled with consternation,
then he nodded and shrugged.


"You're right of course, Lisa," he replied.
Thompson felt slightly disoriented.



Why did the woman's voice suddenly
sound like it was coming from upstairs
instead of behind him?
He pushed himself out of his chair and
spun around, then found himself
imitating the taller Michael.


"Oh, my dear Lord," he muttered,
his voice quavering.
Towering high over him stood the biggest
woman or rather the biggest teenage girl he
could ever have imagined.



She was immense, incredibly,
unbelievably immense.



"Oh my dear Lord. Oh my dear Lord."


"Please don't blame Michael for
lying to you, Sheriff," Lisa said.



"He was trying to protect me."
Lisa took another step into the living room
and straightened completely.
Thompson ran his hand across his forehead
and blinked repeatedly.
He began to lose control of his knees and
felt a seat behind him just in time.


He looked over his shoulder to see the Indian
butler shoving his chair underneath him, a
look of stern disapproval on his face.


"Sheriff Russell Thompson,
I'd like you to meet Lisa Porter,"
Michael said, a tired edge to his voice.


"Lisa, Russell Thompson."



"My dear Lord," Thompson muttered.
"What--what?"


"I'm glad the children were all okay, Sheriff,"
Lisa said as she moved clear of the furniture
and slowly fell to her knees.
Thompson almost leaped out of his chair at the sight.



"Yes-yes, they're fine," he heard himself say.


"Which one was your daughter?"


"Ah-ah, my--Kathy, Kathy's my daughter."


"She has blond hair? I remember her.
She is a very pretty girl."



"Why, I--thank you."
Thompson closed his eyes to fight the sense of disorientation he was experiencing.
He opened them again, but it didn't help.
The giantess was still there, sitting on her heels.
She had to be at least twenty feet tall.
She was so big. He closed his eyes again.



"I am very sorry I lied to you, Sheriff,"
Michael said, walking over to stand beside
Michael's knee.
She reached out to stroke his back.



"I just don't want Lisa getting hurt."


"Her? Getting hurt? What--how--"
Thompson visibly shook himself.


"Please excuse me, but would you kindly
tell me what the hell's going on here?"

Lisa and Michael retold their story to
Thompson while Brian silently served
them all drinks.
Thompson gulped down the cold beer he was offered without tasting it.


"When I saw the children starting jumping
out of the boat I had to act," Lisa continued.


"I waded out to them and carried them
to shore then held them against myself to
keep them warm until help arrived.
Then I took Michael home--he was burned
on his hands saving the teenager who was
piloting the boat and had inhaled a lot of smoke.



We thought that perhaps my appearance
would be dismissed as a fantastic story
created by scared children.
I guess we were wrong."



Thompson shook his head again.
He stood upright and looked at the
amazing couple before him.
The giant teen had wrapped one hand around
Michael's shoulder and upper arm and
he had reached up to stroke her hand gently.


There was an obvious spark between them,
which was more amazing still.


"But-but the government's got to be
informed about this," Thompson began.
"There's got to be something--"


"They already know,"
Lisa replied, her voice flat.
Thompson looked up at her.


"Yes, you told me about your flight from
Brooks Air Force Base." He said.
"But surely there are facilities
better equipped to deal with--"



"Deal with a twenty-three foot woman?"
Lisa finished.



"Sheriff, those people treated me like
I was some sort of specimen in a jar.
I'm never going back to them, ever."


"I won't let them get their hands on Lisa again,"
Michael said at the same time.
Thompson looked from one to the other again.
He rubbed his face over his mouth and chin.


"I keep thinking this is some kind of dream,"
he said softly


“But it's not. It's as real as it can be."
He started laughing, his eyes crinkled.



"I feel like I've fallen into one of those
stories I used to read in comic books.
Look, folks, I-I have no idea what to do about this.
It's not just my girl who's entranced with
the 'big lady', but the entire fourth grade class
from Blessed Sacrament school. Mattie--my wife--
was worried about Kathy telling her how she
wants to see 'the giant lady' again.
You made yourself a lot of little friends out
there on the reservoir today, Miss Porter.”
1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Lisa’s New Life ch  67 -reserved-

1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chapter 73 : Dark Discoveries Part 7

Gail Estate
Friday June 11, 2010
Aprox 625pm



"Please, call me Lisa, Sheriff," she said, smiling.
Thompson was shaking from adrenaline
and surprise.


"Yes, of course. Lisa, I'd like to thank you
for saving my little girl--for saving all the kids
out there today."
Thompson held out his hand.



He was unable to stop all the tremors in his arm.
Lisa's smile broadened and she moved
her hand very deliberately to take
Thompson's hand between her thumb
and forefinger.


"You're welcome--but
Michael helped, too,"
she replied, pressing his hand gently.


"Not as much as you did, sweetheart,"
Michael piped up.
Brian had poured himself a gin and tonic and
now offered a silent toast to the couple.


"Thank you both, then," Thompson replied.
He wiped his brow.



“Boy, I have no idea how
I'm going to explain all this."


"Explain this?" Michael asked.
Thompson saw Lisa's face darken.


"To my wife. Kathy was pestering her
to go back to the reservoir to see the big lady."
Thompson chuckled, then sobered.



"And there are other concerns."
He hesitated for a moment, then told them
about the citizen's militia communiqué.
Both their faces darkened into an angry sadness.


"So, I'm leader of a citizen's militia group, huh?"
Michael growled.


"It's starting to sound like a good idea."


"Michael," Lisa said, admonishing him.
He looked up at her and sighed.
Thompson reached out and touched Michael's shoulder.



"You can be assured that the Department of
Justice will not hear from me," he said.
"You are safe here, at least for the moment.
Though I dunno that I should support your
relationship to Lisa whom doesn’t seem old enough
to consent.


I suppose tho she’s big enough that I can’t
stop you both just please don’t be taking advantage
of her youth and nativity”


“I’m insulted sheriff! Age aside I’m committed
to Lisa and her well being and happiness”
replied Michael.


The sheriff sighed.
“Well I guess you’re bound and determined our
little town err uh county isn’t gonna stay quiet huh?
It’s like when your family started investing here.”


Lisa was clueless on this this one.
The sheriff noticed.
“Right you’re not a local Lisa.
You see the Gail family or rather mostly
Michael here are big philanthropists both in their
previous towns and here.


It was quite the media frenzy for awhile when he
donated to all sorts of causes locally and basically
lifted our local economy up to new heights.
Anyway it’s dinner time and I should take my
leave. Thanks again to you both the town owes
Y’all a debt of gratitude”



DART HQ
Johnston Atoll
Saturday June 12 2010
Aprox NOON local
( still Friday elsewhere )


————-

"Sir? Sir?"
Lang woke suddenly.
He sat bolt upright, blinking to clear the fog
from his eyes. One of the DART team stood over him, shaking his shoulder. Lang squelched a yawn and swallowed to moisten his mouth, grimacing
at the foul taste on his tongue.



"Sir, we just received information from the
Third Team," the private reported, standing at attention beside Lang's cot.
Lang immediately snapped wide awake.


"Where?" he asked.


"Radio shack, sir."


"What time is it?"


"Twelve hundred hours local, sir."


Twelve noon local?
That meant twenty two hundred hours,
Eastern Standard Time--ten o'clock at night in New York. Lang rotated himself out of his bed,
ignoring the creases left in his uniform by his nap,
and left his office.



He wended his way around the other cubicles
and tables crowding the cavernous DART
building towards the one corner filled with
communications equipment, now hidden by
a crowd of DART members.



He coughed loudly and the crowd
opened to admit him.
The two communications technicians
sitting in front of the panoply of
computer terminals were grinning as
one handed Lang a short slip of paper.




Lang read the brief message, then turned on
his heel. He looked up to find himself
surrounded by a sea of bodies.



"Don’t you people have anything better to do?"
he snapped.
The crowd scattered.



Lang clenched the piece of paper in his
hand and turned back to the two
communications specialists.



"Break into the LYCOMING database,"
he ordered.

"Get current names and street addresses
for tax returns on these social security numbers."


Michael and Lisa were yet unaware of
what was coming though Michael had an
uneasy feeling as his new love drifted asleep.
1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Lisa’s New Life ch 68  -reserved-

1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chapter 74 : Dark Discoveries Part 8

DART HQ
Johnston Atoll
Classified location
Saturday June 12, 2010
1230 PM Local
( Still Friday night elsewhere )

——————


LYCOMING was the main information
database for the Internal Revenue Service.
As such it furnished detailed information on
anyone who was listed on the United States'
tax rolls to interested government parties
with the correct access codes, and DART was
unfortunately one of the agencies with access to
the system.



It was only a matter of moments before the
operator established a connection to the government database via modem.



Lang looked at the clocks on the wall.
Thinking about modems make his headache
return despite his nap.
NORAD's planned relocation of the satellite
needed for realtime downloading of the data
compiled by the
Photographic Reconnaissance Office from the KF-11 domestic surveillance vehicle ran into an
objection by some general in the
Pentagon--it was needed for a joint wargames
simulation in Japan--and DART did not have the clout necessary to override the objection.


Lang seethed a bit at the foolishness and
stupidity of the higher ups.



The idea of borrowing one of the nuke sub laser communication satellites from the Navy was met
with an icy reception by Lang's superior Viscount,
and as a result DART was working without a direct connection to its sources of information.




The inferior telephone system had to be pressed
into service instead and the arrival of the
information from PRO had been agonizingly slow;
to make matters worse, all of
Johnston Atoll's telephone traffic was routed
through Hawaii and their lines got screwed
up 5x in the last few days, negating hours of data
which had to be retransmitted.



Lang seethed further!
Nevertheless, Lang had three of his operatives
working in shifts around the clock, viewing and
cataloging all the pictures and data
being sent to them.


Lang watched carefully as the internet
connection was made.
A series of displays flashed across the
computer screen while the technician tapped
quickly on his keyboard.
It seemed to Lang that time was
crawling yet only 10 minutes elapsed between
his request and the resulting readout of the
information he needed.



The technician pressed a key and the
printer chattered to life.
Lang seized the paper as it scrolled out
and tore it, too quickly.
The ragged edge of the paper jammed in the
printer.
Lang ignored the machine's whine of
protest and read the slip of paper in his hand.


Lang walked towards the Logistics section.
"I want a city street map of Minneapolis-St. Paul,"
he said.
The sergeant who rose to attention at his
approach turned and opened one of the file
drawers of the immense map cabinet
behind him.




Lang tapped his foot impatiently as the
proper map was found and spread on the table
before him.
Lang looked at the map, craning his head.
His frown deepened.




"Find me these addresses,"
he snapped,handing the slip of paper to
the sergeant.
His subordinate looked at the number and
name of the street relevant to this particular
map then bent to the map,
running his fingers over its surface.


"Come on, come on," Lang growled.


"Found it, sir," the sergeant suddenly said.
He pointed to a crossroads on the map
in a shaded area.



"Nicolett Avenue and 138th Street, Burnsville.
Nearest military base--Fort Snelling, sir.
The Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport
is within the borders of the base.
From there to target is…six and a half miles, sir."



Lang's brief, wintry smile crossed his face.
He spun on his heel.


“Good now track down the other 2 addresses.
Looks like they’d college addresses though”



"First Team! Second Team!"
he called out.
Eight people broke out of the crowd around him.


"Saddle up. We're heading for Minneapolis.
We will need one restraint pack."


As the teams broke up to prepare for their new
mission Lang felt a hand touch his elbow.
He turned to see the DART medical supervisor
with the remainder of the printout from the
jammed printer in his hand and a
worried look on his face.



"Sir, this Nancy Porter has a husband and two children,"
he said.
"You will need another restraint package at least."


Lang's piercing stare cut the medical
officer off short.
"What makes you think I care about the
ancillary subjects who might happen
to be in the way?"


"But, sir--"


"Fuck them," Lang snapped.
"I suggest that you get back to your original
task of finding a way to restrain our true
target when we find her, Major."



He led his teams out the door to the tarmac,
where their ready transport was being
belatedly warmed up.
Lang sighed. Having his orders questioned
was a bad sign.
The duration of the Paradigm Cordon was
the cause, he thought.



The careful, detailed analyses made of
every possible scenario which could have
called for a Cordon had found no situation
which could not be fully resolved within
twenty-four hours and all of the training and
preparation was with that time frame in mind.



This Cordon was now days old and the strain was
beginning to tell.
With no replacement group for the Cordon
available Lang needed to wrap this operation
up quickly.
He looked up at the sun overhead and felt the
warm breeze as he rode with his team
to the tarmac. It was going to be a good day,
he thought.


Alas his overconfidence would soon once more
bite him in his behind.
1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Lisa’s New Life ch 69 - reserved-

1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chapter 75 : Prelude To Surprise

Gail Estate
Polk County, North Carolina
Saturday June 12, 2010
130 AM


Lisa lay in bed.
She was a bit stir crazy.
Her few minutes of reprieve and first sleep since
becoming a giantess was more a brief power nap.


Lisa had too much on her mind and the insane
stamina? Or was it even stamina? That her growth
bestowed wasn’t the only problem.


She shifted herself carefully so as not to
disarrange the two blankets that covered her.
Her futon now ended at mid-calf when she
straightened herself and her second silk blanket
had to be pressed into service to cover the rest
of her legs.


Lisa laid on her side and faced her doting
new boyfriend.
Michael was on his back, head turned away
from her.
He coughed fitfully in his sleep and
Lisa reached out to rub his chest.


"Shhh, now," she whispered.
Michael sighed and fell into a deeper sleep.
Lisa could feel his chest rise and fall with
each breath.
Her hand was now large enough to overlap
his body at his shoulders.
His skin was dry and warm to her
touch--a slight fever, perhaps.


Lisa recalled all the events that had happened
during this very long day and smiled.
Her smile didn’t last long though.


Although he had refused to admit it their
adventure this morning at the lake had taken
more out of him than he realized.


- Fashback after the sheriff left -


After their remarkable interview with
Sheriff Thompson he had joined her for
supper, sitting cross-legged as before on
her table in the solarium.


Brian somehow fixed just the right
amount of food for her, though by what alchemy
Lisa could not imagine.
While she had made a dainty meal of
3 whole chickens, 3 pots of mashed potatoes
and mixed vegetables and the 3 fresh
loaves of garlic bread
(ignoring how child-sized all her formerly
large eating utensils seemed)
Michael barely picked at his food.


It was clear he held in some concerns.
Lisa didn’t want to pry but she was
unaware what Michael’s concerns were and just
how valid they would prove to be.


Professor Odegard and Doctor Canfield
arrived at mid-dessert. Odegard was pale,
unshaven and gaunt.
There were many books in his bag and
disheveled papers.
He dejectedly reported little to no
success on Lisa’s condition.


This was all unknown territory and contrary
to all known laws of physics.



"I dragged him out of the lab," Canfield admitted.
“I'm afraid my dearest will work on something like
this until he drops."


Odegard managed a wan smile.
"Joann hauled me out the door, saying
something about vending machine food
being bad for me--good thing there are no
vending machines at the lab.
I'll sleep on the problem tonight and come
back to work more on it tomorrow.
Don't give up hope, Lisa.
I'll solve it for you if it's the last thing I do."



"I heard what you did for those children
on the lake today," Canfield said.
"You go, girl. That was a brave and wonderful
thing you did."


"Thank you," Lisa replied.

"Dr. Canfield, I'm glad you're here. It's not me,
I'm fine. Michael got burned in the fire."



"I'm all right," Michael said. He closed his
mouth with an audible snap as
Lisa cast a firm eye on him.
She held out her hands and waited for
Michael to rise to his feet, then lifted him and
put him on the floor before Canfield.



Lisa gasped as Canfield unwound the last of the
gauze from Michael's hands--
the white bandage was stained pink.
Canfield looked carefully at the bright red
sheen of the skin on Michael's hands, then at
Michael.


"I see we're a tough guy," she said, a
sarcastic edge to her voice.
Michael winced as she touched his skin.


"Major first degree burns, almost
second degree.
Not too smart, Michael. You should have
come to the hospital. Well, at least it's a good
job of cleaning and dressing."


“Miss Porter did that," Brian interjected.
Canfield nodded.


"I'll be right back," she said, and turned on
her heel, heading through the inner
portal to the house.



Odegard had put on his half-glasses and
peered through them at Michael's appendages.



"Michael, that has got to hurt.
You stuck your hands in the fire."


"It was the only way I could get the kid
piloting the boat away from the engine fire."
Michael admitted, shrugging.
A giant hand came down and gently
ruffled his hair. He looked up at Lisa,
whose expression was a mix of admiration
and concern.



"Too bad there isn't a way to keep
you from taking risks,"
she said softly, smiling to ease her taunt.


Michael reached up and grabbed her
hand with his own, then let go, grunting in pain.
Lisa made a small sound in her throat and slipped
from her box-chair, her knees thumping the
underside of her table.
She kneeled over him and bent to apply
a kiss to his head.


“Idiot” she sighed.
"Don't ever change, Michael,"
she said into his ear.
He craned his head to smile and
silently say "thank you" to her.



Canfield returned, bearing a traditional
doctor's bag.
Michael suddenly broke into another
paroxysm of coughing.
Canfield fixed him with her 'professional' gaze.


"By all rights I should be
dragging you to the hospital," she said.
"Now, let's reapply something to those
hands and check the rest of you out."


Canfield deftly applied a different ointment
to Michael's hands then rummaged inside
the bag and retrieved two cotton gloves.



She promptly mutilated the fingertips
of the gloves and wormed them on
Michael's hands, then drew out a stethoscope
and listened to his chest and back.


At times she was less than gentle.
To Michael’s protests or yelps of pain she
huffed or had a comeback.

“See this is what comes of being my
most stubborn patient young man.
You’ve been like this ever since I was first your
doctor.”

Michael winced.


“He has?” Asked Lisa.

“Oh yes. When I worked near this idiots
previous home and was filling in for his
regular doctor he had a doozy of a gash
from saving a local girl from some bullies.
Anyway there’s a few stories but those are
for another time.”


She continued her examination.


"Smoke inhalation," she announced softly.
“Possibly inhalation of superheated air as well.
Michael, you need rest.
The burns should heal well by themselves
over the next week, and
that cough should ease in a couple of days.
My prescription is rest, fluids,
these antibiotics--"
she looked uncertain until Lisa lowered an
outstretched palm.



Canfield smiled and put the small
cardboard box in her hand--
"and some cough medicine that I have here--"
and she handed Lisa a small bottle.



"Now, I'll write you another prescription
and call it in to my hospital pharmacy.


Brian can come over tomorrow morning
and pick it up.
I will return here tomorrow afternoon to
replace the dressing.


Lisa, Brian, please see that
Michael does not do a thing for the next
couple of days Especially anything stupid."


"Of course, Doctor," Brain replied.


"No problem, Joann," Lisa added.


"Now wait a minute. Don’t I have a say in this?"
Michael demanded.
Canfield pinned him with a glare.
1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Lisa’s New Life ch  70 -reserved-

1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chapter 76 : Prelude To Surprise
Part 2

Gail Estate
Polk County, North Carolina
Saturday June 12, 2010
130 AM


— Flashback continue to
Earlier that night ——

"Now wait a minute. Don’t I have a say in this?"
Michael demanded.
Canfield pinned him with a glare.


"Don't you sass me, boy.
If I hear you're doing anything around this
place tomorrow I'll personally come
over here and sit on you."


"But, Doc, you've got your own schedule--"


"Michael, you're my patient, too. That's final."


“But doc Brian is my butler he won’t
disobey my wishes” he tried and Brian
grimaced. Lisa spoke up sternly.


“Don’t worry Joann I’ll make sure he
follows doctors.
There won’t be a need for you to sit on him”


“But I”

“No buts! I’ll make you do it if I have to”
said Lisa with a stern glare.

Michael weakly tried a few more protests.
And failed sputtering.


Lisa began giggling.
Odegard regarded his wife with a
fond expression and Brian was smiling from his corner.


Michael turned in a circle, looking
around (and up) at the people surrounding him.
He got his last bit of backbone.


"Now, look here. I am in my own home.
It's just a little burn and smoke, after all--erk!"


Lisa seized Steve, lifting him into her lap.
She settled him on her thigh and looked
down at him, her lips curved into a gentle smile.
He glared up at her.


"Just because you're bigger than me doesn’t
mean you can boss me around--" he began.
Lisa bent to kiss his cheek, her unbound hair
slipping over her shoulder and cascading over
him. His flow of words stopped.


"Oh, yes I can, Michael Porter ,"
Lisa whispered in a low voice.


"Come on, dearest, now I'm going to attend to you,"
Canfield said, abruptly seizing Odegard
by the arm and dragging him towards the front door.


"Good night," Odegard called over his shoulder.


"Don't worry, I'll be back tomorrow."
His wife released her hold on his arm
just long enough to wave at
Michael and Lisa then continued to steer
Odegard towards the front entrance.



Brian leaped in front of them to see them out.
Lisa lifted Michael to his feet to kiss him.
He wrapped his arms along her jawline, kissing
and licking her soft, inch-thick lips.


Lisa leaned forward, her eyes closed,
her concentration focused on the sensation
of what Michael's lips and tongue were doing to
her mouth.
She felt an overwhelming need to hold him
in her arms and suited action to thought.


"Oof,"
he grunted, his arms across her front to
the points of her shoulders.
He grasped her, ignoring the
pain in his hands.



"You feel good. Smell good, too."


"I do?"


"Yes, indeed. Soft and warm, and--"
he sniffed-- "very pleasant."


Lisa craned her head back to look at
Michael as he planted a kiss in the hollow
of her throat.
His hands slipped from her shoulders to caress
her budding breasts.
He looked up at her, his lopsided
grin back on his face.


"A little squishy, though," he said.
Lisa pretended shock.


"Oh?"


"Yep. Warm there, too, if my trip home this
morning was any judge."


Lisa engulfed him in another hug,
squeezing him into her cleavage.


“Pervert”


“Tsundere Ice Queen”


“Baka”


He squeezed her breasts some sending some
pleasure to her.

“You I don't want to share you or
these with anybody else,
I want you and them all all to myself.”


"There's more than enough of me to go around,"
Lisa replied, a little self-consciously.


"More to have, more to love,"
Michael replied. Lisa's smile broadened.


“Idiot”


“Yes but now I’m your idiot!
You’ve turned me into putty in your
soft lovely big hands I dare say”


“Michael”

“Hmm?”

“Thank you Baka”


Lisa rubbed her chin on his head and
squeezed him in her arms.
She began to rock slowly back and
forth, petting and caressing him with one hand.



Lisa hugged him a little tighter.
Michael grunted and Lisa heard a soft pop.
Her eyes flew open in surprise and alarm
and she almost dropped him.


"Oh, God. Michael, did I hurt you?
I was too strong. Did I hurt--"


"No, no. You didn't hurt me at all, pretty lady,"
Michael responded, raising one gloved hand
to still her lips.
Lisa blew out her lips with relief.
Michael grinned.


"Though I will admit a better chiropractic
maneuver I've never experienced,"
he said.
"In fact, it was the only chiropractic
I've ever experienced."


"Oh, you!"
Lisa snorted, the wind of her breath
ruffling his hair as she rolled her eyes.


"Ahem." Lisa and Michael both started at
Brian’'s interruption.
Lisa looked up and saw
Brian standing in the frame of the main door,
his eyes wide, a small smile on his face.


Lisa released Michael and placed him on
the solarium floor.
Lisa noticed faint footprints on the front
of her dress from holding Michael on her thigh.
She brushed the marks away.



"May I point out that it is getting a little late
in the evening, Mr. Gail," Brian said,
bowing slightly.



"Since you are under doctor's orders to rest,
I imagine an early retirement would be appropriate
tonight."


"At least let us have an after-supper drink.
I need something to wash down these horse
pills Doc Canfield left," Michael objected.



"It should help you sleep," Brian agreed.



Lisa had followed Brian and Michael,
dropping to her hands and knees to fit under
the tall door to the living room.
She felt a shiver of claustrophobia in the
confinement of the anteroom and brushed it away.


"We still haven't discussed where we're
going tomorrow,"
Michael said over his shoulder to Lisa.



"Idiot, you can't be serious! Baka,"
Lisa replied as she entered the cavernous
living area and stood to her full height.



"You can't fly that airplane with your hands
bandaged like that, can you? Besides aren’t
they still being worked on?"


"I'll manage," Michael replied with typical optimism.


"Mr. Gail, I must agree with Miss Porter,"
Brian spoke up as he walked towards the
library bar.



“It would be unwise for you to operate an
airplane injured and medicated."


Michael smiled a little, his expression tired.


“Lisa needs to get outside these borders, Brian,"
he replied.


"It's only a matter of time before she's
discovered here.
Even Thompson's promise that he
will not report her presence
isn't a guarantee that we can just stay
here unmolested by government goons
and military douchebags."


"Yes, of course, sir,"
Brian replied.
"However, it would be prudent to allow
yourself one or 2 more days.”


“Michael he's right.
Give yourself a day at least to recuperate,"
Lisa agreed, bending to touch Michael's shoulder.
He looked up at her touch, then looked at
Brian's serious expression. He smiled.



"You're right, of course," he admitted.
A spasm of coughing robbed him of breath
momentarily.


“I'm just worried about you,
Lisa. Still, where shall we go first?
Hokkaido?
Alice Springs?
I'm not so sure about Bahrain,
even if I do know the Sultan's fourth son
personally. Alice Springs might be
the best bet--it's just summer down there
and the weather will be perfect."


He motioned Lisa down to her hands and
knees.


"I can't wait to see you in a bikini,"
he whispered.
"Pervert!" Lisa stood up, blushing hotly.
She planted her hands on her hips.
"You are incorrigible--"

“But you still like me right?”

Lisa blushed!
1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Lisa’s New Life ch  71 -reserved-

1553111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chapter 76 : Prelude To Surprise
Part II

Gail Estate
Polk County, North Carolina
Saturday June 12, 2010
155 AM


— Flashback continue to
Earlier that night ——


“You really are a pervert huh?”


"Okay. Well then, how about Hokkaido?
It's full winter in northern Japan.
I could contract with the shop people to
build you a set of skis and we can shoosh
and plotz down the mountains there."


"I don’t know how to ski,"
Lisa said, smiling in disbelief.
Michael shrugged.


"Neither do I. Good time to learn."


Lisa had slowly seated herself on the
living room floor as he offered one travel
plan after another, each more outrageous
than the previous one.


Brian had slipped into and out of the room,
retrieving a thermos of hot water.
He opened the library bar and began
mixing hot drinks.


Brian placed Lisa’s flower-vase and
Michael's smaller rocks glass on a serving tray
and hefted it over to where they sat.
He had the feeling he’d have to get used to
unconventional drink preparation.


“Alice Springs, then,"
Michael had said after nearly an hour.
“My ranch is perfect. There's a nice,
big pond on the property to take cool dips in
during the day. The sunsets there are spectacular."



Lisa had smiled and nodded her assent.
She had caught
Michael’s enthusiasm and actually began to
feel a sense of anticipation at their impending
trip.



She half-stretched herself out on the floor
beside the couch, facing the fire, caressing
Michael’s back.
Brian had discreetly left the room after serving
them their drinks, his shadow slipping back
and forth from the upstairs rooms towards
Lisa's tent-bedroom.


Lisa had never tasted hot buttered rum before--
Then again she was a minor and technically
therefore not allowed alcohol but given the
situation, her size and all that has happened
Brian felt it okay.
Plus he had been careful to add more non
alcohol components including some water to
the mix.


The drinks Brian had prepared had just
enough bite to give the drinker a warm glow.


“It was just around a couple weeks ago”
she said softly, watching the embers of the
fire in the fireplace sputter and sparkle.


Michael had finished his drink and leaned
into her hand.


"Hmm?"


“Just weeks ago I was an ordinary
Unpopular, plain middle schooler soon to be
high schooler with seemingly no prospects
for luck in the relationship department.
But now days later I'm having the most amazing
experience I could imagine."


Michael smiled but said nothing.
He turned and kissed Lisa's soft, warm palm.
She turned and looked down on him,
a small smile lighting her face.


“In such a short time I met a great guy
who despite being a doting, pervert, Idiot,
somehow managed be as life changing as
another event in my life.


I had a close encounter and I-I began to
grow into a giantess. It's all a little--"


"Frightening?" Michael finished, looking up at
her troubled expression. Lisa nodded.


"Yes."


"Like I told you before, Lisa,
you're a very special person.
You're a good person. Kind. Beautiful.
You're a special girl whose been given a special gift."
Michael rubbed his stubble against her palm.
His eyes began to twinkle and his lopsided grin
returned.



"Anyway, they'll be making television specials
about you one day. ''Lisa Porter’s Amazing Adventures!'
See her do amazing things!
Watch her eat her dinner!
See her walk through her garden!
You'll be famous and do shaving ads and stuff."


Lisa had been torn between distress and
amusement at Steve's stentorian predictions.


"You sound like that TV announcer, Don Pardo,"
she said.
“Or Rod Serling.
Christ knows he could probably write the script of
my life for the last several days,”


"It's funny, I never watched much TV
when I was growing up,"
Michael replied, chuckling.
"Pop and Mom always wanted me to hit
the books. Thank God for that."
He rose from his seat and reached out his arms to
Lisa. She obligingly lifted him up until their
faces were level with each other.



“Lisa I love you,"
he said softly, reaching out with one gloved
hand to tweak her chin.



"I won't care if you are never famous.
I don't care if you are--"
he looked her up and down--
"well, however tall you are now, or grow to
twice or 3x this size.
I just hope that you will never leave me."



His admission of his love for her melted
Lisa's heart. Her eyes were wide and she blushed.
She brought him close and kissed him.
His lips tasted of rum and butter, and she smiled.


"I will never leave you as long as you never
leave me”


“I’d rather die or deal with Canfield at her
angriest”


Lisa chuckled.
She cocked her head at him.
"You look tired. Let's go to bed."



"Okay by me. I am tired, for once.
I hope you don’t mind--"


Lisa chuckled once more.


"I'll live without it for one night--but only one,"
she replied, her smile broad.
She licked at him once, his stubble rasping
her tongue.
He tried mouthing her tongue but settled
for a long, passionate kiss instead.


"But will I?" Michael sighed as they parted.
"Gotta get well fast."
Lisa experienced another surprise as they had
prepared for bed.
As he had done every morning since she arrived
Brian had straightened up her tent-bedroom and
shower area.



Lisa appreciated the fresh sheets on her bed mat
and the washed neatness of her towels
